text: [Music]
when I was uh 55 years old and I had
been at the FED 30 years and decided
that I was the number two officer of the
New York fed uh first vice president
that they weren't going to make a lawyer
the president of the New York fed I
decided it was time to move on and I uh
called various people I knew in the
neighborhood and amongst was Hank
Greenberg and I went and met with Hank
and he was the
fastest uh he said he' give me a call in
two weeks which he did wages hours
conditions of employment and I had no
idea what I was going to do and I don't
think at that time he had any idea what
I was going to do I worked for Hank for
a year and I called myself and it it was
the role that I carried up mostly at AIG
I was a firef fighter uh for him where
there was a problem dealing with that
problem went off going to the going into
the next problem and it also gave me a
chance to to learn the company I mean it
was huge compound complex uh I got to
meet people uh in the United States and
abroad and get a feel for the company
and then I became general counsel uh
there but uh working for Hank was a was
a delight not withstanding his
reputation well one he certainly is uh
tough and resilient those all of those
stories are true there's another side of
the man about how concerned he is about
employees how much loyalty and how
important
loyalty uh was with him uh you know
stories about when a head Auditor in
Asia had a heart attack in Thailand Hank
stayed up all night on the phone with
doctors from New York hospital with
doctors in in Thailand he would the uh
star foundation and I don't know if he
started this or carried it out he may
have started it uh every employee for
AIG and agents of AIG in the United
States and abroad and these were agents
who were as in Asia they only sold AIG
products got a scholarship if their
child went to an English language
college uh the scholarship amount was
something like 10 or
11,000 and there had to be Financial
need if if the child if there was no
Financial need because the parent was
making a large enough salary at AIG so
when one looked at the staff
foundation's annual uh IRS report name
of individual after individual after
individual and and I really learned the
scope of it one day uh when I was in the
private dining room waiting for a guest
and this uh gentleman uh a waiter who
was obviously from mainland China and I
asked him what he was going to be doing
Labor Day and he said he was driving to
Cambridge and I said well why are you
driving to Cambridge well he said he was
taking his daughter first generation
American American Born MIT and called it
sty scholar so for people like him that
individual this was rather
significant and and and that's something
that he that he really kept up with of
course the amounts of money he gave and
the foundations gave to health and
medical you see that at New York
Hospital uh and but but most of all he
truly cared about employee loyalty was
loyalty was extremely important to him
and I think that came out of perhaps his
army experience you know when he he
enlisted underage in the Army uh and
when you're in a platoon you develop
that amongst people and he he would
sometimes say something like I wouldn't
be in a foxhole with that person which
again goes to loyalty and Trust he
decided that uh I guess the the head of
the staff Foundation was going to be
stepping aside uh Florence Davis who was
the general counsel was going to become
the head of the staff Foundation I think
Florence still is uh and he asked me to
be general counsel and that was
a a unique experience in that I had
reorganized the legal department at the
New York fed when I was there as general
counsel at AIG I had to reorganize the
uh the legal department and put it into
some semblance and it took a while to
get a feel for people uh and that really
for the
first I would say nine months to a year
was my major task uh was organizing this
gigantic uh legal department and even
when I left eight years later I'd say it
was still a work in
progress
